Posts.Content: By chance was she  ever on the chemo Taxotere?  I did four sessions of it and had delayed symptoms very similar to the ones she describes, months after I completed the chemo the symptoms emerged.
Posts.Title: my friend has pain all over after treatment. Any Ideas?

Posts.Content: Eventually the pain did go away. During that time I was prescribed a medication for nerve pain called Gabapentin, I found it to be quite effective.  I hope your friends pain can be remedied because it is impossible to deal with anything until we get the pain part under control.  All the best to her.
Posts.Title: my friend has pain all over after treatment. Any Ideas?

Posts.Content: I would really like to see one of the experts reply to this topic.  Why would a doctor offer tamoxifen if there was no cancer diagnosis?  And furthermore ever refuse to do a biopsy on any "palpable abnormality"?  I was under the impression that was more of a medical term for "I can feel a lump".  Personally, I have no experience with cystic breasts so I am unfamiliar with any of its characteristics, and I really hope that is what this is.  Please let us know as those of us who reply are interested.  Those of us who urge you to get further testing done and sooner rather than later, do so not to scare you or encite panic, but rather because we know first hand the devastation that can be the result of waiting when we should have been more persistent.  I allowed a surgeon with 20yrs experience continually put me off and not do a biopsy because they were "absolutely positive" my lump was not cancer, I was too young, I was breastfeeding so it was just mastitis, or just an abcess, were the assurances they gave me.  I now have metastatic breast cancer. I am now leary of any assurances, without the cold hard evidence of a pathology report which only came from a biopsy, not a mammogram or ultrasound which I had and still yielded no definite answers.
Posts.Title: Hello..I have a few questions...

Posts.Content: Since I've been diagnosed with locally advanced breast cancer in November 2006, I've done endless reading on the subject and you have 2 symptoms that cause red flags to go up, namely:  discharge from the breast, and the rough skin and large pore descriptions of the skin on your breast (I've heard Inflammatory Breast Cancer symptom described as the skin appearing to look like that of an orange peel).  It sounds like your doctor needs to do further testing.  Mammograms do not always detect breast cancer (i.e., inflammatory breast cancer).  I had a mammogram and ultrasound, but it was the biopsy that determined my diagnoses of BC.  Good luck to you, but be persistant until you get answers, and get them ASAP.
Posts.Title: Hello..I have a few questions...

Posts.Content: I think, however I'm not positive, hopefully one of the experts on the board will respond, that in order to positively diagnose IBC, a skin biopsy of the site must be included.  Definitely get a second opinion from someone who has previous experience with IBC.
Posts.Title: IBC - question and concern

Posts.Content: Speaking from personal experience, absolutely DO NOT wait 2-3 weeks.  Insist on the biopsy ASAP even if you have to sit in his office and refuse to leave until you are tended to.  My tumor became so large in such a short time I had to have chemotherapy before surgery to shrink the tumor first before they could remove it.  It was 9 cm when they did my mastectomy.  To determine for sure whether this is IBC they must also do a skin biopsy of the area as well.  My breast cancer has now metastisized to my lung - I believe due to the fact my surgeon was not vigilant enough at the beginning.  Time is crucial.
Posts.Title: Inflammatory breast cancer

Posts.Content: I don't know about Inflammatory Breast Cancer but I had what is called Locally advanced Breast Cancer.  My lump went from the size of a dime (flat and hard like bone) to the size of my fist in 2 months.  There are two other women in my support groups with the same story.  I was in a clinical trial and the breast clinic I was a patient in were seeing about 2-3 cases of locally advanced breast cancer a month.  I would make sure you get your biopsy asap because if this is Locally Advanced, you don't want to waste any time.  Good luck to you.  Hopefully this is something benign.
Posts.Title: Inflammatory breast cancer

Posts.Content: I don't have any experience myself with Lymphedema but there is a girl in my support group who was just recently diagnosed with it.  She benefits from Lymphatic drainage massage; and also wears a compression sleeve.  She is young and a bit concerned about the fashion side of wearing a sleeve, but through some research on the internet found a place in San Fransico (I believe) that makes and sells "fashionable" compression sleeves.  I will ask her the exact link at our next meeting.  Apparently Lymphedema is a side effect that all of us who've had mastectomies run this risk of acquiring, and I've also been told that the risk is there for our entire lives.  At my breast cancer clinic (in Canada) there is a nurse who runs a "Lymphedema Clinic" in response to decades of complaints by those who've had mastectomies with no avenue for relief.  Ask your Onclologist if such a clinic exists in your area.  Hope this helps.  Let me know if you'd like the link.
Posts.Title: Lymphadema

Posts.Content: In my chemo education class, which was offered and recommended to everyone prior to starting chemo, we were advised to gargle with a mixture of warm water and baking soda 3 times daily just as a matter of routine even in the absence of mouth sores.  Of course I didn't do it, but started once I noticed the mouth sores starting to crop up, and it definitely helped.  I had to stay away from all spicey foods during chemo and for about a month afterwards.  I suppose the chemo just heightens the sensitivity of your senses.  Eventually you will be able to go back to the foods you enjoy as I did.
Posts.Title: side effects?
